subject: Llama 4 Rumors 🗣️, Krea raises $83M 💰, Amazon Nova Reel 📹
body:
Sign Up |Advertise|View Online 
TLDR 

Together With ￼
TLDR AI 2025-04-08
This AI Startup is Reinventing Marketing—and Investors Can Still Get In Early (Sponsor) 

RAD Intel is making marketing feel human again. Forget interruption—this patented AI reveals exactly who your customers are, what they want, and the perfect (human) personality to deliver it.

Backed by industry Adobe and Fidelity Ventures Hasbro, RAD Intel is already turning heads, attracting major investment, and redefining digital marketing for brands like Hasbro, MGM and Sephora.
Insiders from Google, Meta and Amazon have invested and now, you can too.
Shares are currently $0.55 per share, but not for long. On Apr 10, the share price changes - so nows the time.
Jump in at the current share price of $0.55 
🚀
Headlines & Launches
Meta Responds to Llama 4 Rumors (1 minute read) 

Meta's VP of Generative AI has denied claims that Llama 4 models were trained on benchmark test sets, pushing back against allegations of inflated performance scores. 
Amazon Nova Reel 2-Minute Videos (3 minute read) 

The updated Nova Reel model now supports multi-shot videos up to 2 minutes long, offering more creative control and efficiency for generative video content. 
Investing in Krea (3 minute read) 

Andreessen Horowitz has announced an investment into Krea, a platform combining AI models to help creatives generate and edit visual content. Used by teams at Pixar and Samsung, Krea now has over 20M users. The company plans to launch an enterprise-grade product later this year. 
🧠
Research & Innovation
One-Minute Video Generation with Test-Time Training (12 minute read) 

This work introduces Test-Time Training (TTT) layers, featuring highly expressive hidden states, to overcome the limitations of standard Transformers and alternatives like Mamba in generating long, coherent videos. By integrating TTT layers into a pre-trained model, they demonstrate the generation of coherent one-minute videos from text storyboards that significantly outperform baseline methods in telling complex stories according to human evaluations. Tom and Jerry cartoons are the test bed. 
Scaling Speech Language Models (14 minute read) 

This study finds that speech-language models initialized from text models using interleaved training scales more efficiently than speech-only models. 
Benchmarking Web Agent Capabilities (16 minute read) 

Online-Mind2Web is a realistic evaluation benchmark for autonomous web agents. Current models perform worse than expected due to flawed benchmarks. 
🧑‍💻
Engineering & Resources
Register Now for AI Disrupt: The Reliable AI Leadership Conference (Sponsor) 

Hasura's AI Disrupt will bring together industry leaders and decision-makers to explore the integration of AI with existing systems, focusing on accuracy and transparency. Attendees can expect engaging panels, case studies, and hands-on workshops, all led by experts at the forefront of AI innovation. See the full speaker list and register for free 
VarGPT (GitHub Repo) 

Dual understanding and synthesis model in a single autoregressive framework. This means that one model can caption and generate images. 
FlexTok (GitHub Repo) 

OpenSource work from Apple. It follows up the company's paper from a few weeks ago that allows images to be tokenized in a variable number of tokens. This means that more complex images can use more tokens. 
Adaptive Gradient Clipping (GitHub Repo) 

ZClip uses EMA-based gradient norm statistics to adaptively suppress outlier gradients, preventing loss spikes and improving training stability without static thresholds. 
🎁
Miscellaneous
Google's AI Highlights in March (4 minute read) 

Google recaps major March updates including Gemini 2.5 Pro, expanded AI Overviews, AI Mode, and other feature rollouts across its products. 
Genies AI avatars (23 minute read) 

Genies has launched a no-code platform that enables anyone to create intelligent AI avatars with unique looks, personalities, and behaviors for use in customizable gaming experiences called Parties. These AI avatars are powered by large language models, behavioral AI, and real-time animation tech, allowing dynamic interactions, gameplay, and emotional responses. 
OpenAI Plans O3 and O4-Mini Release Before GPT-5, Altman Says (3 minute read) 

OpenAI will release intermediate models o3 and o4-mini before GPT-5. This staggered release is due to technical complexities with GPT-5, allowing improvement and better handling of expected demand. The shift comes as competitors like Google's Gemini 2.5 Pro advance in the AI field. OpenAI has just secured a $40 billion funding round. 
⚡
Quick Links
OpenAI's o3 model might be costlier to run than originally estimated (2 minute read) 

Arc Prize Foundation has revised computing cost estimates for OpenAI's o3, suggesting it's much higher than initially thought at potentially $30,000 per ARC-AGI problem. 
Bringing multimodal search to AI Mode (2 minute read) 

Google is expanding its AI Mode feature to millions of U.S. Labs users, enhancing it with multimodal capabilities. 
Goku Video Model (5 minute read) 

Goku from ByteDance is a flow based video generation model of 2B and 8B parameters with 160M image and 36M video pairs.

subject: The all-new Levo Gen 4 is here
body:
Not Displaying Correctly? Tap to view in browser 
￼ 
Accessories
Bikes
Clothing
Clearance
￼ 

The most advanced Levo yet. The Gen 4 packs more power, longer range, and smarter tech into a redesigned chassis that’s built to handle anything. With next-gen motor, fully adjustable geometry, and seamless integration, it’s the ultimate trail machine – dialled for control on the climbs and confidence on the descents.
FIND OUT MORE 
 
￼ 
Power Meets Precision: The Heart of the Levo 4 
 The Specialized 3.1 motor delivers up to 666W and 101Nm of torque for smooth, intuitive power on technical climbs and tricky trails. Unlike basic eMTBs, it keeps strong torque across all cadences – giving you control when and where you need it most. 
Designed for the Trail, Built for the Long Haul 
 With 150mm of travel, adjustable geometry and internal SWAT storage, the Levo 4 frame is built for serious riding. A secure battery setup and lifetime bearing warranty add confidence for the toughest trails. 
￼ 
￼ 
Genie Suspension: Unrivalled Control 
 The Genie dual-air system boosts traction with a softer initial stroke and firmer end-stroke, preventing bottom-outs. It offers 11% more usable travel than before – with better support on bigger hits. 
Advanced Geometry & Mixed Wheels 
 The Levo 4’s geometry hits the sweet spot between stability and agility. With a mixed-wheel setup and tunable angles, it’s ready for steep descents or switchback-filled climbs. 
￼ 
￼ 
Battery & Range: Go Further 
 With up to 1,120Wh capacity, the Levo 4 offers huge range. Choose between the stock 840Wh battery, lighter 600Wh option and add a 280Wh Range Extender for over 5 hours of ride time. 
MasterMind TCU & Specialized App 
 The MasterMind TCU highlights the adjustable power modes, offers real-time ride data, and connects to the Specialized App for tuning, tracking and added security – including System Lock and Apple Find My. 
￼

subject: Get ready for one hell of a ride!
body:
￼
￼
NO PAVEMENT. NO MERCY.
Get ready to hit the road this weekend in an expanded French countryside, just in time for the Paris-Roubaix Femmes avec Zwift.
Conquer new badges, routes, and challenges in homage to the “Hell of the North”—one of the most iconic races in the world!
 
￼
With eight new routes in France, there is no shortage of options to queue up in My List.
￼
Conquer five of the new routes to complete the Hell of a Route Chaser challenge and unlock multiple XP bonuses!
￼
For each of the first four routes you complete in the challenge, you’ll earn a 250 XP bonus, and for the fifth, you’ll earn 1000 XP!
 
￼
Hell of the North
We’re going all out for the Paris-Roubaix Femmes avec Zwift with Fondo-style race events April 11 – 13, hosted on the new routes in the France expansion.
Join us for the climbs, cobbles, and chaos and you’ll unlock the Paris-Roubaix Femmes avec Zwift Cap to rep on your next rides!

subject: We have updated our Privacy Policy
body:
View online
￼
Dear Roger,
 
We have updated our Privacy Policy. The updates include:
 
	•	new methods of personal data collection, such as through travel document checks and your myRyanair account; 
	•	more details about the types of personal data we may process, including information contained in travel documents and biometric data; 
	•	more details about why we process personal data, such as for verification purposes and fraud prevention; 
	•	new information on personal data we may share with our partners, including approved online travel agencies and travel document validation services; 
	•	additional information on how long we keep your data; and 
	•	 simplified outlines of your rights and limitations that may apply 
 
You can find our Privacy Policy at https://www.ryanair.com/gb/en/corporate/privacy-policy.
 
Yours sincerely,
Ryanair

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online 
TLDR 

Together With ￼
TLDR AI 2025-04-07
You've heard the hype. It's time for results (Sponsor) 

See what agentic AI can really do on April 10.

After years of siloed experiments, proofs of concept that fail to scale, and disappointing ROI, most enterprises are stuck. AI isn't transforming organizations — it's adding complexity, friction, and frustration. 
But Writer customers are seeing positive impact across their companies. Our end-to-end platform delivers adoption and ROI at scale. We're applying that same technology to build agentic AI that actually works for enterprises. Join us for a live product release on April 10 at 2pm ET (11am PT).
Can't make it? Register anyway and we'll send you the recording!
Register Now! 
🚀
Headlines & Launches
Llama 4 (6 minute read) 

Meta has unveiled Llama 4 Scout and Maverick, two 17B parameter multimodal models that offer state-of-the-art performance on major benchmarks, along with Llama 4 Behemoth, a 288B model still in training that surpasses GPT-4.5 in STEM tasks. 
Midjourney V7 (2 minute read) 

Midjourney has released its new image generation model, V7 alpha. It brings smarter text interpretation, better image coherence, and introduces Draft Mode for fast, low-cost iterations with optional voice commands and personalization. 
Cyberattacks by AI agents are coming (7 minute read) 

AI agents are emerging as potent tools in cybersecurity capable of executing complex attacks and potentially scaling operations like ransomware. The LLM Agent Honeypot project aims to detect these agents by simulating vulnerable servers. Its work has revealed that agents can adapt and avoid detection better than traditional bots. Experts anticipate an increase in agent-driven cyberattacks, urging preemptive development of defenses as these technologies evolve. 
🧠
Research & Innovation
Unsupervised Panoptic Segmentation (3 minute read) 

CUPS is a new method for panoptic segmentation without labeled data that leverages depth and motion cues to train directly on scene-centric images. 
Rope to Nope: Hybrid Attention for Long Context (25 minute read) 

The key innovation that enabled Llama 4 to reach 10m+ tokens in context is the alternation between no positional embeddings and rotational positional embeddings. While there are only have benchmarks on Needle in the Haystack, it seems to be a strong confirmation of performance of alternating layers. 
Inference-Time Scaling for Generalist Reward Modeling (31 minute read) 

This paper from DeepSeek talks about how to use inference time scaling to make reward modeling better to bootstrap stronger reasoners. It hints at a broader strategy from the Chinese start-up to use its existing reasoning models as the base for a new generation of reward models to train the next generation of reasoners. 
🧑‍💻
Engineering & Resources
Generative Modeling for Crystals (GitHub Repo) 

CrystalFormer is a transformer model that generates crystal structures using space group symmetry, making crystal generation more efficient and data-friendly. 
Nano Aha Moment (GitHub Repo) 

A single file, single GPU, from scratch full parameter tuning library that replicates DeepSeek R1-Zero style training. 
Object Counting (GitHub Repo) 

A fully automated zero-shot object counting method leveraging feature maps and self-attention mechanisms that achieves state-of-the-art accuracy on the FSC147 dataset. 
🎁
Miscellaneous
DeepSeek 1.58bit GGUF (Hugging Face Hub) 

The unsloth folks have figured out which piece of the new R1 model can be properly quantized. They also found some tokenizer quirks to be aware of, which make quantization slightly harder. In summary, just the MoE layers go to 1.58 bit while everything else remains in 4 or 6 with their dynamic quantization scheme. 
AI masters Minecraft: DeepMind program finds diamonds without being taught (5 minute read) 

DeepMind's AI system, Dreamer, successfully learned to collect diamonds in Minecraft without prior human guidance, highlighting a step towards general AI systems. Using reinforcement learning, Dreamer independently explores and builds a model of the game environment to predict future actions and outcomes. This advancement suggests potential applications for AI in real-world scenarios where trial and error are costly. 
The artifact isn't the art: Rethinking creativity in the age of AI (6 minute read) 

AI-generated Ghibli-style visuals have surged in popularity, straining OpenAI's servers and sparking debates about creativity in the AI age. While AI can rapidly produce artistic images, it lacks the human ability to experience and synthesize complex ideas and emotions. The future of creativity will focus on meaningful outputs shaped by human insight and purpose, with AI as a tool rather than a creator. 
⚡
Quick Links
Granite Speech 8B (Hugging Face Hub) 

IBM silently launched a state-of-the-art speech recognition and understanding model based on its Granite series. 
Start building with Gemini 2.5 Pro (1 minute read) 

Google's Gemini 2.5 Pro is now in public preview via the Gemini API on Google AI Studio, with Vertex AI availability coming soon. 
OpenAI's models 'memorized' copyrighted content, new study suggests (3 minute read) 

A study suggested that OpenAI trained its models on copyrighted content without permission.

subject: Get ready for upcoming changes: important information from Companies House
body:
￼



This is an official email to your registered email address from Companies House.
In this email: 
	•	reminder about changes introduced in March 2024
	•	new financial penalties
	•	get ready for identity verification
	•	register as an Authorised Corporate Service Provider (ACSP)
	•	changes to accounts
	•	how to keep up to date
We introduced the first set of changes under the Economic Crime and Corporate Transparency (ECCT) Act on 4 March 2024.   
We’re introducing more changes over the coming months that could affect you.   
Over time, these changes will improve the accuracy and transparency of the data on our registers and strengthen our approach to tackling economic crime.  
Find out what you need to do and when.    

Reminder about changes introduced in March 2024 
On 4 March 2024, Companies House introduced new rules for registered office addresses. All companies must, at all times, have an ‘appropriate address’ as their registered office.        
There’s also a new requirement for all companies to give a registered email address to Companies House. 
You must keep your registered office address and your registered email address up to date to make sure you receive important information from Companies House.  
We may take action against the company and its officers if you do not meet these requirements. 
For more information about the new rules for registered office addresses and the new registered email address, read our guidance on GOV. UK.    

New financial penalties   
We introduced new financial penalties in October 2024. You may receive a financial penalty if you do not comply with your legal obligations – for example, not filing your confirmation statement on time.  
We’ll introduce more financial penalties for non-compliance as and when new measures come into force.   
Read more about how we’ll use our enforcement powers to issue financial penalties.  
Sign up for email reminders to remind you when your confirmation statement is due.   

Get ready for identity verification
Anyone setting up, running, owning or controlling a company in the UK will soon need to verify their identity to prove they are who they claim to be.   
You’ll be able to verify using GOV. UK One Login, or through an Authorised Corporate Service Provider (ACSP). 
To get ready for identity verification, it’s important to make sure we hold the correct details for each officer and person with significant control (PSC) of your company.   
You will not be able to complete identity verification if the personal information on your identity documents, such as your date of birth, does not match the information held on our register.  
Check the details we hold for you and your company on the Find and update company information service.   
You can tell us about some changes online. For other changes, such as incorrect or missing information about directors or PSCs on your incorporation documents, you'll need to file a paper form. 
In the future, identity verification will become compulsory. From this point, if you or any other directors do not comply with identity verification requirements on time, you’ll be committing an offence and will not be able to make any filings for your company. There’ll be a range of consequences, including a financial penalty and being unable to start a new company.  

Register as an Authorised Corporate Service Provider
Third-party providers such as agents or accountants, who wish to carry out identity verification checks on behalf of clients for Companies House, can now register their business as an Authorised Corporate Service Provider (ACSP).   
To become an ACSP, also known as a Companies House authorised agent, third-party providers must be supervised within the UK by a relevant Anti-Money Laundering (AML) supervisory body.   
To register as an ACSP, third-party providers will need to use our 'Apply to register as a Companies House authorised agent' service. 
Read more about what it means to be an ACSP.

Changes to accounts
The online accounts and Company Tax Return service is closing on 31 March 2026. 
If you use this service to file your accounts with Companies House and Company Tax Return with HMRC, you’ll need to find alternative filing methods once it closes. 
Over the next 2 to 3 years, we’ll be transitioning towards filing accounts by software only.  
We’re preparing a detailed timetable and we aim to give companies 21 months’ notice ahead of the change. Most companies can make the change now as software is already available. We’ve published an updated version of our Find software for filing company accounts tool to help companies to choose a suitable software product. 

How to keep up to date
Read all the latest updates on our Changes to UK company law website and sign up for our regular email newsletters.   

You’ve received this email because you provided this registered email address to Companies House. You cannot unsubscribe from emails to the registered email address as this is a legal requirement under the Companies Act 2006. We will only use this email address to communicate about your company. The registered email address will not appear on the public register.  
To change the company’s registered email address, go to: find-and-update.company-information.service.gov.uk/registered-email-address  
Please email enquiries@companieshouse.gov.uk if you did not provide this email address as a registered email address.

subject: Your Week Ahead
body:
￼
￼
Welcome back to another fun week on Zwift. Stay active with a fresh weekly routine and sign up for this week’s most popular events.
And there’s even more to explore with This Season on Zwift. From advanced goals and fitness tracking to outdoor ride stats, it’s all designed to level up your ride. Plus, you can roll through new roads in an expanded France, customize your HUD, and more!
New season. New tools. Same you—just stronger.
EXPLORE EVENTS
￼
Hell of the North
￼
 
APRIL 11-13
We’re going all out for the Paris-Roubaix Femmes avec Zwift with Fondo-style race events, hosted on the new routes in the France expansion.
Join us for the climbs, cobbles, and chaos. You’ll unlock the Paris-Roubaix Femmes avec Zwift cap to rep on your next rides!
SIGN UP
￼
MvdP: Fun is Going Full Gas
￼
 
APRIL 9
This workout is inspired by Mathieu van der Poel to boost your explosive power.
Mathieu has an incredible ability to accelerate, seemingly at will, and keep extreme pressure on to break his competitors. This ability is called anaerobic capacity and is what this workout will be focused on improving.
SIGN UP
￼
Fitness Tracking
Zwift is making it easier than ever to track your fitness in the Zwift Companion app.
Starting April 8, view your indoor and outdoor rides in one place, track progress with real-time feedback, and stay motivated with goal tracking and streaks. Everything in one place.

￼
New Streak Flair is Here!
Show off your streak with different Scottys, depending on the length of your Zwift streak. From a Scotty medallion to a Scotty hitching a ride in your jersey pocket—flex your hard work!
Plan your week with My List on the Zwift Companion app or jump into an event that keeps you motivated.
LEARN MORE
￼
One Hell of a Ride
Starting April 7, you’ll have access to eight new routes in France, with more climbs, cobbles, and chaos than ever before—all in time for the Paris-Roubaix Femmes avec Zwift!

subject: Y13 - end of term - important info and updates - with thanks
body:
Dear Parents and Carers
 
Please find below an email with some key dates and information which has been sent to your young person today. 
 
May I also take this opportunity to thank the many hundreds of you who filled in the Ofsted survey feedback. 
 
The inspection team tell me that the response numbers from parents is unprecedented. Thank you. 
 
Inspectors finish with us today and we should have a report and outcome to share with you in six weeks’ time.
 
Wishing you and your family a restful break over this holiday period.
 
Best wishes
 
Jo Trump
 
 
 
￼
 
Dear Y13
 
Here we are already at the end of your penultimate term at Hills Road.  Hard to believe that there’s just half a term to go before you’re ready to take on the world and of course, those exams.
 
Thank you to all of you for being your usual excellent selves this week when we have been hosting our Ofsted visitors. They finish with us today and we should receive their report in about six weeks’ time. Whatever the outcome, I know they have been so impressed with you all, as we are every day. Thank you.  
 
As we start to look ahead to what’s next, do make use of the great collection of top tips, podcasts and resources to help you study and revise effectively over the coming weeks in the run up to exams. Our lovely Study Skills team have put together some brilliant materials and suggestions that are available here: https://hrsfc.sharepoint.com/sites/StudySkillsStu
 
Further important information about exams, key dates and other reminders are all in the update email below - please do have a careful read through. And make sure you save the date for the leavers’ event on 26 June!
 
Keep the next few weeks in perspective and keep focused on your goals. There is no outcome that could happen that will mean there is no path forward for you. There is always a path! Keep going and keep your eyes on the horizon and on those opportunities ahead. You will be just fine.
 
And do take a look at the latest edition of Hills News for a snapshot of all the amazing things you’ve all been up to this past term from the magical Corn Exchange evening back in March to this week’s sunshiny fun run. Hills News Spring 2025. So many fabulous achievements and stories! Just imagine all the further great opportunities that are out there for you too once you get to the other side of exam season.
 
Make sure you take time to enjoy the Spring sunshine and make sure you get a good break this holiday alongside the revision you’ll have planned. 
 
Take care of yourselves, Y13.
 
Jo Trump
Principal
 
￼
 
In the remaining weeks after Easter, most subjects will have finished their specification and will be focused on supporting you with revision and examination question practice. 
 
Time in lessons will be spent in honing your subject knowledge and applying it successfully to examination material to support you to the best possible outcomes. 
 
Please do not confuse revision lessons with revision you can do at home by yourself. There is distinct value to focused revision that is guided by a teacher and supported by the knowledge and combined expertise of your whole class.  It is in these lessons that teachers can draw your attention to common student errors and remind you of important exam advice. All timetabled lessons and support sessions remain compulsory, and count towards your overall attendance percentage.
 
￼
 
All the indications from the March Progress Reviews are that as a year group you are making good progress in your A Level subjects – well done! We are confident that, as a year group, you are well placed for your exams in May and June.  Keep acting on the advice and feedback you received from teachers and make use of all the subject workshops and other support on offer.
 
￼
 
You will have received your exam timetable by email several weeks ago.  Please continue to check carefully for further information from the Exams Office as the exams draw nearer.  Teaching will finish at the end of the day on Friday May 9th, with public exams starting the following a week in some subjects.
 
This year, it is the case in that a significant amount of the examined assessment will be completed by May half-term in numerous subjects, a trend that has emerged since the return to exams after the pandemic.  Business, Classical Civilisation, Combined English, Economics, English Language, English Literature, Film Studies, Geography, History, History of Art, Media Studies, Music Technology, PE, Philosophy, Psychology, Philosophy, Music Technology and AS Further Maths will all have held between 50% and 100% of the examination element of their final qualification by May half-term so do plan your revision to take this in to account.
 
Finally, don’t forget that you need to keep the afternoon of Wednesday 11 June, along with all day Wednesday 25 June free as these are the national exams contingency sessions.  Awarding bodies will make use of these days were it to be necessary to postpone any exams for any reason and reschedule them.  It is an arrangement that is put in place every year, so no leaving the country on holiday until after these dates please!
 
￼
 
Friday
9
May
Final day of teaching
Monday
12
May
Study leave and exams begin
 
 
 
 
Wednesday
11
June
Exam contingency afternoon – keep free
Wednesday  
25
June
Exam contingency day – keep free
Thursday
26
June
Leavers’ Party
 
￼
 
 
Safeguarded hours
 
As a reminder, updated hours during which the College is a safeguarded site are from 8am to 5pm. This allows us to ensure we have the appropriate level of wrap around care, should a safeguarding incident occur. Students are expected to leave the site by 5pm.  
 
Should there be a need to stay after 5pm, students must have a staff member who has agreed to take responsibility for them the whole time they are on College site. This staff member will notify the Caretaking team with details of where the students are and inform them when they are leaving. This is so that in the event of a fire or safety incident, we know who is on site and where they are.  
 
If you have been supervised by a member of staff after 5pm, please be aware that the access gates will remain closed after college hours. You should therefore leave site via the main reception. 
 
 
￼
 
We hope that you enjoyed the Employer Fair. I have no doubt that the employers attending enjoyed meeting you and I do hope that you have found it useful.  
 
It’s been lovely to hear about university and apprenticeship offers and gap year plans from Year 13s. Lots of you are still waiting to hear from universities, but they should all reply to you by 14 May. You have, in most cases, until 5 June to reply to your offers. Do look back at the Whole Cohort Presentation ‘Firm and Insurance Choices and Student Finance’ if you need help with this.
 
If things haven’t worked out how you hoped they would, or you still need support with your plans, please do get in touch with Careers.
 
If you are planning to apply to university in your gap year, keep reading your emails for information on how to do this. Also put 23 June in your diary as the date for the Gap UCAS Registration Day, where we will support you with your plans. Do click on this link to join the Year 13 ‘Gap Year Team’, if you haven’t done so already. 
 
And please do ensure that you complete the Year 13 Leavers’ Survey, which you were sent recently. As well as giving us helpful feedback on what we do well and what we can do even better, this is where we can make sure we have an accurate record of your future plans as well as your private email address so that we can get in contact if we need to once your College IT accounts are closed down in the autumn.  
 
￼
 
As we look ahead to the summer term, Hills Road Sixth Form College Performing Arts Department are very excited about next term’s programme of events.
 
American Psycho – a Musical will be running from 23 to 27 April and Wuthering Heights will run from 25 to 27 June. Make sure you get your tickets!
 
As a reminder, tickets for all of our shows are available from: www.ticketsource.co.uk/hillsroadsixthformcollege
 
We hope to see you at one of these upcoming productions!
 
￼
   Please remember that there are resources available to you on the SharePoint site here, which includes links to external support available during the break. 
￼
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 P Please consider the environment and don't print this email unless you really need to.

subject: Your invitation to inspiring evening talks this April at Hills Road Sixth Form College
body:
￼
  Dear all,  Please find below some details of our next exciting talks in the series of 50th anniversary events.
 

 
￼
A Career in Law: What Do Barristers and Judges Really Do? Her Honour Judge Helen Arthur  📅 Wednesday 23 April ⏰ 7:30 pm 📍 The Hall, Hills Road Sixth Form College 🎟️ Free to attend but book in advance   Have you ever wondered what life is really like for a barrister or judge, bearing the weighty responsibility of making decisions that impact people’s futures?  Hills Road alumna Helen will share her experiences from over 20 years in family law. First as a barrister, now as a Circuit Judge on the Midlands Circuit, Helen’s work involves some of the most complex and sensitive legal cases.   After Hills Road, Helen went on to study Law in London before becoming a family law barrister, representing parents, children, and local authorities in cases that shape lives.  Whether you’re a young person considering a career in law, fascinated by how our justice system works, or simply curious about Helen’s journey, join us for what promises to be an engaging and thought-provoking evening!
Sign up for 23 April with Her Honour Judge Helen Arthur
￼
An evening with a Bestselling Author Sarah Vaughan   📅 Tuesday 29 April ⏰ 7:30 pm 📍 The Hall, Hills Road Sixth Form College 🎟️ Free to attend but book in advance   International bestselling author, former Guardian journalist and former Hills Road parent Sarah Vaughn, read English at Brasenose College, Oxford and went on to train at the Press Association.  She is perhaps best known for her breakout thriller Anatomy of a Scandal, now a worldwide number-one Netflix series, as well as Little Disasters, recently adapted into an upcoming 'tense and compelling' TV drama to be released this Spring.  Sarah was told she couldn't be a journalist as she wasn't tough enough. Applying to Oxford, she was told to a women's college, or she would never get in. She ignored both bits of advice, and now, aims give Hills Road students the inspiration she never had aged 16-18! Sarah will talk about her career to date, overcoming challenges, and offer inspiring insights into working in the world of journalism, publishing or TV.
Sign up for 29 April with Sarah Vaughan
 
 
We hope to see you soon and hope you enjoy a restful Easter period.
 
Best wishes,  Hills Road Marketing Department

 

 P Please consider the environment and don't print this email unless you really need to.

subject: Fw: Update on HMRC Making Tax Digital changes
body:
More red tape quarterly reporting for landlords...

Claire Pembery
Finance Director
 
St Bede’s Inter Church School
Birdwood Road
Cambridge
CB1 3TD
01223 568816
 

From: Azets <makingtaxdigital@azets.co.uk>
Sent: 04 April 2025 10:03
To: Claire Pembery <CPembery@stbedes.cambs.sch.uk>
Subject: Update on HMRC Making Tax Digital changes
 
View in browser 
￼ 
￼ 
Update on HMRC Making Tax Digital changes
 
The way income tax self assessment returns are submitted with HMRC is changing.
 
Making Tax Digital (MTD) for Income Tax will require sole traders, the self employed and landlords with qualifying income to maintain digital records and update HMRC each quarter as opposed to submitting one annual tax return.
 
HMRC will be running high profile advertising campaigns to raise awareness of the change from April 2026 when the changes start to come into effect. 
 
Key information on qualifying income levels
This change will be introduced in three phases:
	•	from April 2026, for those with qualifying income over £50,000
	•	from April 2027, for those with qualifying income over £30,000
	•	from April 2028, for those with qualifying income over £20,000
From April 2026, those in scope for MTD for Income Tax will no longer submit an end-of-year tax return through HMRC’s online filing service. They will need to make their end-of-year final declaration using HMRC approved MTD software.
 
Those impacted by the new legislation will be contacted by HMRC this April, and we are also contacting those clients directly whom we believe are in scope to help assist with getting ready in good time for the change. 
 
If we have not contacted you directly and you believe that you fall within the scope as outlined above or you receive a letter from HMRC, advising of the changes, please contact us via MakingTaxDigital@azets.co.uk so that we can get in touch to help you.
 
What does the introduction of MTD for Income Tax mean?
To comply with the requirements, those affected must:
	•	keep their records digitally
	•	submit digital quarterly updates to HMRC
	•	use MTD-compatible software to file income tax returns
We are here to help
Where applicable, our dedicated Digital Delivery team is available to assist with:
	•	Selecting, implementing, and setting up a compliant MTD solution
	•	Providing ongoing support for a smooth transition
For more information on the requirements, including FAQs, click here.
CONTACT US 

￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼

subject: DeepMind AGI Safety 🦺, OpenAI Nonprofit Guidance Commission 👥, Hate Speech Benchmark 📚
body:
Sign Up |Advertise|View Online 
TLDR

Together With ￼
TLDR AI 2025-04-04
Agentic AI is Changing Everything We Know About Process Orchestration – Learn How (Sponsor) 

Traditional automation is no match for today's complexity. Agentic workflows—autonomous, goal-driven agents collaborating to achieve business goals—require more than prompt engineering. They need a powerful workflow engine to orchestrate tasks, decisions, and outcomes at scale—with humans in the loop when it matters most.
The latest webinar by Orkes explored how combining agentic AI and process orchestration can enable businesses to integrate AI-driven decision-making, streamline workflows, and scale with ease. Tune in to learn:
	•	Why Traditional BPMN Tools Fff
	•	rations to financial services
Watch the recording 
🚀
Headlines & Launches
DeepMind's Approach to AGI Safety (11 minute read) 

Google DeepMind outlines its perspective on building safe and secure artificial general intelligence, emphasizing oversight and technical safeguards as AGI capabilities progress. 
OpenAI just made its first cybersecurity investment (3 minute read) 

OpenAI invested in Adaptive Security, a startup using AI to simulate and train employees against social engineering hacks. Adaptive Security secured $43M in Series A funding, with plans to bolster its platform amid growing AI threats. Co-founded by veteran entrepreneur Brian Long, the startup has quickly amassed over 100 clients since launching in 2023. 
OpenAI Nonprofit Guidance Commission (3 minute read) 

OpenAI is forming a new expert commission to shape how its philanthropic arm supports communities using AI, aiming to align AI innovation with real-world nonprofit needs. 
🧠
Research & Innovation
Articulated Kinematics Distillation from Video Diffusion Models (18 minute read) 

This work introduces Articulated Kinematics Distillation (AKD), a framework that leverages skeleton-based animation and generative diffusion models to produce high-fidelity, physically plausible character motions with reduced complexity. It ensures structural consistency and outperforms existing methods in 3D coherence and expressive motion quality by using Score Distillation Sampling to guide joint-level control. 
Enhanced LoRA-based Fine Tuning (18 minute read) 

MetaLoRA introduces dynamic parameter generation using meta-learning principles, enhancing the flexibility and task-awareness of LoRA-based fine-tuning strategies. 
Backdoor Attacks in CLIP (19 minute read) 

CLIP models are highly vulnerable to poisoning backdoor attacks, achieving nearly 100% attack success with minimal poisoned data. An efficient detection method is to use local outlier detection to uncover unintentional backdoors in existing datasets. 
🧑‍💻
Engineering & Resources
Flash Attention reimagined with Kvax (Sponsor) 

Nebius open-sourced Kvax: a JAX-based Flash Attention implementation optimized for long-context training. Achieve faster, denser packing and state-of-the-art performance with context parallelism and efficient doc mask computation—built by Nebius' AI R&D team.
Read more here and explore the code 
Large Small Net (GitHub Repo) 

A new family of lightweight vision models inspired by the dynamic heteroscale capability of the human visual system, i.e., "See Large, Focus Small". LSNet achieves state-of-the-art performance and efficiency trade-offs across various vision tasks. It introduces a new type of convolution kernel. 
Pplx Cuda Kernels (GitHub Repo) 

Perplexity has released some of its MoE kernels, which outperform DeepSeek at scale while being slightly more flexible and less opinionated about the MoE architecture. 
HateBench for Evaluating Hate Speech (6 minute read) 

HateBench provides a framework for evaluating hate speech detection models on LLM-generated content along with a manually annotated dataset and code for analyzing adversarial and stealthy hate campaigns. 
🎁
Miscellaneous
Zonos TTS (8 minute read) 

A compelling Apache 2.0 model for speech generation and voice cloning. It has multi language support and expressive real time generation. 
Hugging Face's AI Agents Course (14 minute read) 

Hugging Face released an AI agents course today. This free course will take you on a journey, from beginner to expert, in understanding, using, and building AI agents. 
Google is shipping Gemini models faster than its AI safety reports (4 minute read) 

Google has launched an AI reasoning model, Gemini 2.5 Pro. The model leads in coding and math capabilities, but Google hasn't released safety reports yet. Google plans to publish these reports after collecting feedback from experimental releases, though this approach raises transparency concerns. Despite pledges for transparency, Google seems to prioritize speed in model deployments, diverging from industry norms for responsible AI practices. 
⚡
Quick Links
Code with Claude Developer Conference (1 minute read) 

Anthropic has announced its first developer event focused on hands-on sessions and best practices for building with Claude - it is set to take place in May in San Francisco. 
The LLM Course from Hugging Face (2 minute read) 

Hugging Face has revamped its popular NLP course into a broader LLM curriculum with expanded chapters on fine-tuning, reasoning models, and modern AI agent workflows. 
Devin, the viral coding AI agent, gets a new pay-as-you-go plan (2 minute read) 

Cognition launched a $20 entry-level plan for its AI programming tool, Devin, which has been improved to handle complex coding tasks better.

subject: Trump Tariffs
body:
HI All, 
 
Hope you are keeping well? 
 
I thought I would send an email out given the recent market events of “Liberation Day”. There is and will be a lot of press I dare say many of you have read or will be reading, I thought I would give a summary below:
 
What just happened?
 
President Trump has delivered his “Liberation Day” announcement, ending weeks of anticipation and speculation. The measures were toward the more extreme end of expectations. We will try not to reprise what is widely available in the press, but it’s worth a quick reminder on the background behind last night’s executive order.
 
Very early in his second term, President Trump ordered the US Trade Representative to investigate potential trade frictions imposed by America’s trading partners which might cause their exports to America to be more competitive than America’s exports to them. He asked for it to be a thorough review going beyond tariffs to also include non-tariff barriers.
 
What was announced?
 
Despite decades of progress in reducing tariffs and trade barriers, there remain frictions and to some extent these are inevitable. 
 
	•	At the end of March, this report was produced and based upon it, the administration has determined that every country exerts protectionist policies which the US needs to reciprocate. That includes 115 countries with an identical implied tariff on US imports of 10% which will be fully reciprocated and 75 countries with implied tariff rates of greater than 10% which will be partially reciprocated with tariffs ranging from 10% to 50%
	•	This comes after tariffs which President Trump introduced during his first term on China and metal imports. This year he has now raised tariffs in China three more times – reaching a cumulative rate of more than 60%. This includes tariffs related to fentanyl imports which also apply to Canada and Mexico. Sector specific tariffs of 25% have been announced on US imports of steel, aluminium, cars, and car parts.
	•	The impact of this is significant. The average tariff suffered by US imports has risen by around 20% so far during his second term. He has indicated further tariffs will come to cover pharmaceuticals, semiconductors, lumber, and copper.
 
Market reaction 
 
	•	Although Tariffs were priced into market to some extent, the level imposed is worse than the market expected. The reaction has been consistent with ongoing concerns that this will dampen growth.
	•	Equity markets sold off globally.
 
What’s the context? 
 
	•	In the short-term, the tariff news likely could worsen the recent weakness evident in consumer and business confidence. 
	•	Combination of the uncertainty and long-lead times makes it unlikely that corporates would be willing to commit meaningful investment to bring manufacturing back to the US. The US is a high-cost location to manufacture most goods. And there is no certainty of the duration of the current policy.
	•	Lots of US companies used their pricing power to raise prices during the recent wave of inflation. That was during a time when the US government was handing consumers stimulus cheques and so could afford the higher prices. While some corporates will try to pass on in pricing, it’s not as clear that they will be as successful this time round given the weaker consumer. It's therefore a risk for corporate margins.
	•	For many non-US companies, the tariffs are a major challenge, not least for European and Asian auto makers which have a 25% tariff imposed from today.
 
What’s next? 
 
	•	It is possible that headline tariff rates are negotiated down in the coming days, ahead of their imposition, and/or over the coming weeks and months. 
 
There is no question that the impact of these tariffs is negative for the global economy. There are environmental and social consequences of trade, but it is economically positive, and its curtailment is a headwind. He has already signalled his willingness to negotiate, and the unpopularity of prices increases should encourage him to come to the table, so it would not be surprising to see these tariff rates reducing over time in a succession of announcements.
 
Of course, investing is always fuelled with volatility, appreciate recent periods given pandemics, wars etc have exacerbated that in recent years. This arguably is a follow on from that. We have been in situations like this before and things have and can turn quickly in markets. 
 
If you have any major concerns or fears, please reach out and we can have a chat.
 
All the best,
Gary 
 
Gary Edwards, DipPFS, Cert CII (MP) Director

PRE-ORDER NOW

Cambridge Corn Exchange, run by the not-for-profit Cambridge City Council, depends on ticket sales, sponsorship, donations, memberships, grants, and concessions to bring top-quality shows to the city. By becoming a member, you make a significant impact, helping us continue to deliver the music, comedy, and performances you love. As a thank you, we offer great perks in return.

￼
￼
￼
￼
Cambridge Corn Exchange is operated by the not-for-profit Cambridge City Council. As well as Corn Exchange ticket income, we rely on income raised through sponsorship, donations, memberships, grants and concessions to ensure that we can continue to bring the biggest and best shows to the city.
 
We also organise an annual programme of diverse and greatly valued events including free Fireworks Night, Out of the Ordinary Festival and Music in the Parks. These events are free in order to offer residents the opportunity to participate in the cultural life of the city and to provide access to all. They contribute to creating a united city, ‘One Cambridge - Fair for All’, in which economic dynamism and prosperity are combined with social justice and equality. Again, these events are also an opportunity to develop valued partnerships with local businesses and other organisations that make up the Cambridge Community.

subject: News & Club Runs
body:
View this email in your browser 
￼ 

Dear Roger,

Sunday Club Run
Photo's from last week...
￼ 
6th April 2025

We meet outside The Norris Museum on The Waits, St Ives at 8:45 with the first group leaving at 9:00 prompt.

This week's club run will be heading to Waresley.

Groups A and B will ride the same route of 57 miles stopping at Bean Theory in Waresley.

Group C will ride the shorter route of 34 miles also stopping at Bean Theory in Waresley.*

*The pace of the C group is around 14-16mph giving opportunity to new riders to join us.  Please welcome new riders to this group.
Sunday Long Route - 08 - Waresley
Sunday Short Route - 115 - Waresley

Thursday Evening Ride
Facebook Event Page - Please show support to get these rides kick started 👊
1st May 2025

We meet outside The Watch Office Bar & Kitchen on The Boulevard, Alconbury Weald at 18:15 with the first group leaving at 18:30 prompt

EVENING RIDES RESTARTING ON 1ST MAY!!
	•	Routes will be here the week before each ride.
	•	Multiple paced groups.
	•	2 routes
	•	25 - 35 miles
	•	No stop ride
	•	The Watch Office Bar & Kitchen will be open until 11pm.
	•	Free Parking available outside The Club gym and near The Pavillion.
	•	New riders are welcomed so please bring a friend.  Membership is required after 2 club rides for insurance purposes.
Thursday Long Route - TBA
Thursday Short Route - TBA
Polite Reminders (for all club rides):
	•	Download the route.
	•	Remember your cafe bike locks.
	•	Look after your club mates.
	•	TT/Aero bars are not to be used.

Thank you.


Upcoming events in the SICC Calendar
For more information please click on the buttons below which will take you to our members only Facebook page.

We always hope for good numbers so that we can form suitable pace related groups.  Please hit 'GOING' to show support.  Thank you. 
Ladies Social Ride
Double Dutch, Ship of the Fens Audax
Peaks Away Day Club Run
Ladies Road Ride

Saturday 12th April 2025

A few ladies are available, please join us!  You're welcome to bring a friend, new riders are always welcomed.  Full details will be in the event page soon and included in the club email sent out on 10th April.

We will meet outside The Norris Museum on The Waits, St Ives at 8:45 with the first group leaving at 9:00 prompt.

The route will be around 30-40 miles and will include a cafe stop.  This is a social ride, no one will be dropped.

This may be the last official club ladies ride for a while as our evening rides restart on 1st May.

Thanks
Nat
Double Dutch, Ship of the Fens Audax

Saturday 19th April 2025

ENTER ONLINE HERE

Peaks Away Day Club Run

Sunday 5th May 2025

Book a place to stay!!  OR drive down for the day!

We will be meeting in Hathersage outside the swimming pool.
There's a car park at the swimming pool, a pay and display opposite and other parking options in the town. Please allow plenty of time to get parked and make your way to the meet point. There's also toilets and a newly refurbished cafe at the pool if you wanted a pre/post ride coffee. They're open 8am-5pm and they're expecting us.

Meet: Oddfellows Rd, Hathersage, Hope Valley S32 1DU
Time: 9.15am (to be arranged into groups)
Depart: 9.30am
Route: https://ridewithgps.com/routes/45989392
Pool Cafe: https://www.hathersageswimmingpool.co.uk/.../the-pool-cafe/

It would be a good idea to carry snacks and gels on the bike and maybe extra supplies in the car.

The Old Smithy Cafe in Monyash (mile 38) and Hassop Station Cafe (mile 44) are marked on the ridewithgps route. There's also plenty of places to stop in Bakewell. Please take a look before the ride. We can agree in our groups when we would like to stop.  The Pool Cafe will allow us to catch up at the end.

Please feel free to use this Facebook event page to arrange car shares.
Now's the time to start training!  ￼

Please hit 'GOING' on Facebook to show support. Thank you. 

2025
Dates for your Calendar
 
	•	Social Evening (off the bike) - Tuesday 25th February
	•	International Women's Day Ladies Social Ride - Saturday 8th March
	•	Ladies Social Ride - Saturday 12th April
	•	Double Dutch Audax - Saturday 19th April
	•	Easter Club Run - Sunday 20th April
	•	Evening Social Rides (Alconbury) Start - Thursday 1st May
	•	Peaks Away Day Club Run - Sunday 4th May (stay for the weekend, it's a Bank Holiday!)
	•	Evening 10 mile Time Trials Restart (Sawtry) - Wednesday 14th May
	•	Club Summer BBQ Club Run - Sunday 29th June
	•	Summer Blue Egg Ride - Saturday 19th July
	•	Last Evening 10 mile Time Trial (Sawtry) - Wednesday 20th August
	•	Bank Holiday Weekend Longer Club Run - Sunday 24th August (ideas welcome!)
	•	Last Evening Social Ride (Alconbury) - Thursday 28th August
	•	Dave Nelson Memorial Hill Climb - Wednesday 3rd September
	•	Cafe Ventoux Away Day Club Run - Sunday 7th September
	•	Remembrance Club Run - Sunday 9th Novemeber
	•	Christmas Dress Up Club Run - Sunday 21st December
	•	Festive 500 - Wednesday 24th - 31st December
	•	Winter Blue Egg Ride - Saturday 27th December
	•	Short New Years Eve Ride - Wednesday 31st December
 
	•	SICC hosts Eastern League CX - TBC
	•	Christmas Meal - TBC
	•	AGM & Awards Presentation - TBC

 
Club 10m TT's & Hill Climb
(dependent on volunteers and an Events Officer being appointed to the committee ASAP)

￼ 
This is Marta Gamez, a researcher at Anglia Ruskin University (Cambridge) in sport and nutritional science.

We are currently doing a series of free online talks that cover aspects of scientific evidence in areas of nutrition and training for cyclists and would like to kindly ask you to circulate this among your club as members may find this of interest.

The first event is on the 3rd of April 6-7pm. There is more info on the link to the event. Please feel free to share it! 

We are confirming speakers/dates of next talks, but they will all become available on our Eventbrite page.

If you can share the link /information above it would be great.
Any questions, please let me know.
 
Thank you very much and have a great weekend!
Marta M. Gamez-Fernandez
Research Fellow |Exercise and Nutritional Science
Cambridge Centre of Sport and Exercise Science
Anglia Ruskin University | Cambridge | UK

subject: Durham Newswire April 2025
body:
All your latest news and events
 
View in browser
 
 
￼
 
 
 
Newswire
April 2025
 
 
 
Do we have the correct details for you?
Current postcode: CB4 3NZ
Current professional position: Senior Technical Engineer
 
Update my profile
 
 
 
Your alumni newsletter 
Our community has much to be proud of - this issue is packed with uplifting stories and good news. We have marked our international impact during Durham Global Week, and also through successful ‘Durham Days’ celebrations. 
Explore our latest news below.
 
 
 
￼
 
Engaging students as drivers of change 
 
The Coimbra Group Climate Symposium marked its 40th Anniversary in Durham. The two-day event explored the role of universities as agents of transformative change for climate, nature, planetary health, and society.
Pictured (left to right): student participants from the University of Bergen, Norway; Durham University, UK; and the University of Iași, Romania. 
 
Read more
 
 
 
￼
 
Northern Lights A Cappella hat-trick at UK ICCA
 
Our premier student vocal group has been crowned UK champions of the International Championship of Collegiate A Cappella (ICCA) competition for the third time in a row.
 
Read more
 
 
 
￼
 
Uniting Durham alumni around the world
 
The vibrant Durham Days celebrations saw alumni get together in 41 cities internationally as part of Durham Global Week 2025.
Pictured: celebrations in Milan, Italy 
 
Read more
 
 
 
Research to empower and inspire
 
We conduct innovative and impactful research to transform lives and make a difference globally and locally. 
 
￼
 
In a spotlight series of articles, we highlight Professor Carlos Frenk’s work on dark matter. His pioneering work has fundamentally shaped modern cosmology and our understanding of the Universe. 
Image courtesy of Amanda Benson, BBC 
 
Read our latest research

 
 
 
Our Community
 
 
 
￼
 
Congratulations to our Durham Global Week 2025 award winners
 
Professor Simon Croft (Zoology, St Cuthbert’s Society, 1968-71; Honorary Doctor of Science, 2022) was awarded the Alumni Global Impact Award at the end of a successful Durham Global Week. 
Pictured: Professor Simon Croft (winner of the Alumni Global Impact Award; second from left) and Professor Paul Denny (winner of the Individual Award; second from right) with Professor Claire O’Malley (centre) 
 
Read more
 
 
 
￼
 
Unearthing a major Iron Age discovery: an alumna reflects on her involvement
 
Recent graduate Faye McLean (Archaeology, Trevelyan College, 2020-24) helped to excavate the highly significant Melsonby Hoard during her time as a student. 
 
Read more
 
 
 
￼
 
Ranked among the world’s best 
 
We achieved our strongest-ever performance in the prestigious QS World University Rankings by Subject 2025, with a record 21 subjects ranked among the world’s top 100.   
 
Read more
 
 
 
￼
 
New University Chair of Council appointed
 
Caroline Johnstone has been appointed to the position following a robust and competitive process involving our staff and students. She will take up her voluntary role in August 2025.
 
Read more
 
 
 
Class Notes
 
We’re proud to celebrate your successes and achievements.
 
￼
 
Ahella El Saban (MA in Marketing, 2010-12), features in Forbes Middle East’s 100 Most Powerful Businesswomen 2025. She commented: “It is an honour to be part of the list that holds such accomplished and inspirational females.”
Melissa Bryant (Politics, Ustinov College, 2013-14)
Dr Helen Frisby (Theology, St Mary's College, 1997-2000)
Dr Michael Garbutt (English Language and Literature, Hatfield College, 1973-76)
Glyn Gowans (Law, Hatfield College, 1972-75)
Rupert Hague-Holmes (Law & Politics, University College, 1984-87)
Dr Asha Hornsby (MA in English Literary Studies, St John's College, 2014-15)
Richard Ovenden OBE FRSA (Economic/Modern History, St Chad's College, 1982-85)
Kiran Ruparelia (Accounting & Finance, John Snow College, 2014-18)
The Durham Alumni chess team, featuring Sam Walker (History, University College, 2013-17), Phil Purcell (Natural Sciences, St Cuthbert's Society, 2013-16), Will Taylor (Natural Sciences, College of St Hild & St Bede, 2008-12), and Phil Manning (Sociology, Van Mildert College, 1982-84).
Why not share your own news with us?
 
Read more

 
 
 
Lifelong learning
We have a wide range of postgraduate study options for you to continue your education and programmes for working professionals.  
You can also browse a range of scholarships, including our alumni fee scholarship and new postgraduate student support scholarship. 
Read more
 
 
 
Get Involved
 
 
 
￼
 
Our new online shop launches with 10% off
 
Check out our brand new website for official University merchandise and benefit from 10% off any orders over £20 when you sign up to the shop’s newsletter. 
 
Read more
 
 
 
￼
 
Chat to us about your time at Durham: College telephone appeals underway
 
If you’re an alum of the College of St Hild and St Bede, St Mary’s College, or Van Mildert College, you might receive a call from one of our friendly telephone appeal callers.
 
Read more
 
 
 
￼
 
Shakespeare Recovered: Durham’s First Folio exhibition
 
For the first time in over a decade our edition of William Shakespeare’s First Folio will be on display as the centrepiece of a new ‘Shakespeare Recovered’ exhibition in Cosin's Library, Palace Green.
 
Book your free ticket
 
 
 
View all upcoming events
Check our events pages regularly for all the upcoming alumni events across the world, and how you can join in.
Events calendar
 
 
 
Colleges
 
 
 
￼
 
Ustinov College 60th Anniversary
 
Our postgraduate community was founded in 1965 as the Graduate Society before becoming Ustinov College in 2003. Join us as we celebrate this milestone.
 
Read more
 
 
 
￼
 
Alumni donations bringing Grey College tennis court back to life 
 
The tennis court at Grey is getting a new lease of life as a multi-purpose games arena. We’re thankful that alumni donations have made this refurbishment possible. 
 
Read more
 
 
 
￼
 
Josephine Butler College celebrates connections with annual networking dinner 
 
Alumni and current students came together last month for an evening of meaningful conversations, career insights, and professional connections. 
 
Read more
 
 
 
￼
 
First ever ball held at South College 
 
A masquerade theme with electronic clay pigeon shooting, mini golf, tarot card readings, poker, live music and a DJ entertained students in a glamorous first for South College. 
 
Read more
 
 
 
￼
 
St Mary’s College 125th Anniversary weekend welcomes over 70 alumni 
 
Saturday 22 – Sunday 23 March saw attendees enjoy a dinner, honour the late Joan Kenworthy (a former Mary’s Principal) by unveiling a portrait, and watch a special anniversary play.
 
Read more
 
 
 
Read more from our Colleges
Explore our College pages to discover the latest news.
Read more
 
 
 
Retail
 
 
 
￼
 
Play your part in shaping a sustainable future
 
Remember your time here, and reduce waste at the same time! Reuse, refill, refuel anywhere with one of our reusable cups or water bottles.  
 
Shop now
 
 
 
Want to read more?
If you liked these stories, take a look at the latest Durham news, featuring current research and thought leadership, student and alumni news, and more. 
Explore more
 
 
 
Durham University takes pride in the achievements and contributions of its 230,000 alumni and supporters. Stories that cite views, talks and published work reflect the individual's contribution in their personal or professional capacity and do not represent the University's position or endorsement.
Newswire is curated by Editorial Group members Lucian Hudson (Chair), Glen Whitehead, Claire Whitelaw, Tristan Alltimes, Vicky Fisher and Debbie Mayne, and assembled by Hamish Lehan and Jo Coombs.

Week 2:              7th – 11th April 2025 
Week 3:              13th – 18th April 2025 (including Good Friday) 
 
On the first Monday of the course, Isaac should report to our Brookside site (3-4 Brookside, Cambridge, CB2 1JE) at 08:30 for full day and half-day mornings. If their first session is not at 09:00, they should report to Brookside 30 minutes before their scheduled start time.
 
Isaac will receive their timetable and further welcome instructions. On subsequent days, students will go directly to classroom for the start of the lesson.
 
IMPORTANT IT INFORMATION – PLEASE READ THE ATTACHED IT DOCUMENTS AND FOLLOW THE LINK BELOW:
Acceptable Use Policy for Easter Revision Students - Cambridge 2025 
Isaac should bring paper, pens, an electronic device (laptop or tablet) if available, any other materials that would normally be used in their lessons (dictionary, calculator, maths set, etc), class notes and textbooks.
 
Full-day students are provided with a lunch, and everyone is provided with drinks/snacks at break times.
 
Please note that there is no student parking at MPW.
For students who are driving our advice is to use park and ride facilities
https://cambridgeparkandride.info
 
We look forward to seeing Isaac at Easter. Please check the details carefully and should you have any queries in the meantime, please do not hesitate to contact us.
 
For those students staying in accommodation at Corpus Christi College please see the next page.
 
MPW Cambridge Easter Revision Team
CambridgeEaster@mpw.ac.uk
01223 350158

If the student will be arriving after this time, please let us know as soon as possible. 
 
If there are any problems reaching us on the day, please call: 07376 778324.

Cambridge

subject: Anthropic’s LLM for Education 📚, AI & UFC 🥊, Claude for US Government 🇺🇸
body:
Sign Up |Advertise|View Online 
TLDR 

Together With ￼
TLDR AI 2025-04-03
Reach millions of tech decision-makers with TLDR (Sponsor) 

Advertising in TLDR puts your brand directly in front of tech leaders when they're most engaged. With 10 interest-based newsletters, you can easily reach a targeted audience of developers, PMs, marketers, and executives. Learn more about advertising with us. 
🚀
Headlines & Launches
Anthropic's LLM for Education (3 minute read) 

Anthropic has introduced Claude for Education, which has features like Learning Mode to promote critical thinking and broad university access through partnerships with major institutions and education platforms. 
Claude Available for U.S. Government Use (2 minute read) 

Claude has achieved FedRAMP High and IL-2 compliance through Google Cloud's Vertex AI, making it usable by federal agencies and defense organizations with strict security needs. 
Meta and UFC partner to enhance fan engagement with AI and VR (3 minute read) 

Meta Platforms and the Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) have entered a multiyear partnership to integrate Meta's AI and VR technologies into UFC events. This collaboration aims to provide fans with immersive experiences using platforms like Meta Quest and AI-powered glasses. Meta's branding will feature in the UFC's Octagon during events and Threads will serve as the official social media partner. Financial terms were not disclosed. 
🧠
Research & Innovation
Paper Bench (12 minute read) 

OpenAI has released a new benchmark for academic paper creation. It requires full replication of certain papers, including understanding their experiments, results, and creation of novel ideas. 
Geometry Crafter (11 minute read) 

A powerful model that uses video diffusion as a prior for consistent geometry estimation over time. It runs about 1.5 FPS for full point cloud estimation and can also do proper camera pose estimation. 
Enhanced Cell Segmentation (14 minute read) 

CellVTA improves vision transformer-based models for cell instance segmentation by injecting high-resolution spatial features through a CNN-based adapter, achieving state-of-the-art performance on multiple datasets. 
🧑‍💻
Engineering & Resources
DSO: Aligning 3D Generators with Simulation Feedback for Physical Soundness (5 minute read) 

Most 3D synthesized data is generated for aesthetic quality. However, that means that when they are put into physics environments, they cannot stand up or be self supported. This work fine-tunes a model slightly to make it more physically plausible. 
Medical Reasoning Dataset (GitHub Repo) 

A large-scale medical reasoning dataset built to support faithful and explainable problem-solving in LLMs that aims to push forward research in medical AI. 
DeepMind's Study for Kernel Fuzzing (22 minute read) 

Snowplow is a kernel fuzzer with a learned white-box mutator that improves test mutation efficiency, significantly increasing code coverage and bug discovery in Linux kernel fuzzing. 
🎁
Miscellaneous
Satya Nadella: DeepSeek is the new bar for Microsoft's AI success (12 minute read) 

Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella emphasized the importance of turning AI research into successful products following an $80 billion AI investment. The company is focused on improving its AI offerings, like Copilot and Muse, while ensuring investments align with sustainability goals. Microsoft aims to be carbon-negative by 2030 despite challenges posed by increased AI workloads. 
Alphabet's AI drug discovery platform Isomorphic Labs raises $600M from Thrive (1 minute read) 

Isomorphic Labs, spun out of DeepMind, raised $600 million from Thrive Capital to further develop its AI drug design platform. The funding will also support hiring top researchers and advancing discovered drugs to clinical trials. Notably, Isomorphic Labs has partnerships with Eli Lilly and Novartis for its AI model. 
The hottest AI models, what they do, and how to use them (7 minute read) 

This article outlines the top AI models released since 2024, highlighting their uses and strengths. Notable models include OpenAI's GPT-4.5 Orion, which has strong world knowledge; Google's Gemini 2.5 Pro, focused on coding; and Cohere's Aya Vision, which excels in image tasks. The overview aims to simplify navigating the rapidly evolving AI landscape. 
⚡
Quick Links
DeepSite open source canvas (Hugging Face Hub) 

DeepSite is a DeepSeek powered open source canvas for “vibe coding” that updates apps in real time while the system writes the code. 
NotebookLM Adds Web-Based Source Discovery (2 minute read) 

Google's NotebookLM now includes a Discover feature that pulls in curated web sources based on a user-defined topic, streamlining research and information gathering. 
AI-Powered Conversational Videos (4 minute read) 

Tavus uses Llama 3.3 to power realistic AI-generated video conversations by combining visual question-answering and multi-image reasoning for lifelike digital interactions. 
Love TLDR? Tell your friends and get rewards! 
Share your referral link below with friends to get free TLDR swag! 
https://refer.tldr.tech/b8c44167/2 

Track your referrals here. 
Want to advertise in TLDR? 📰 
If your company is interested in reaching an audience of AI professionals and decision makers, you may want to advertise with us. 

Want to work at TLDR? 💼 
Apply here or send a friend's resume to jobs@tldr.tech and get $1k if we hire them! 

If you have any comments or feedback, just respond to this email! 

Thanks for reading, 
Andrew Tan, Ali Aminian & Andrew Carr

Trouble viewing this email? Read it online 

￼
On sale this week
￼
￼
THE WORLD OF HANS ZIMMER - A NEW DIMENSION
Tickets on sale now
Get Tickets
￼
MONSTER JAM RAMPED UP
Get presale tickets from 9am today
Get Tickets
It's All Happening
Top shows you won’t want to miss 😍
The epic sounds of Hans Zimmer are coming to Birmingham and get ready for an adrenaline-charged weekend this September as Monster Jam Ramped Up™ is back! 

This weekend, Hot Wheels Monster Trucks: Glow-N-Fire takes over Utilita Arena Birmingham! At bp pulse LIVE, Pakistan’s Qawwali legend Ustad Rahat Fateh Ali Khan graces the stage on Friday, while the iconic Gabrielle delivers her career-spanning hits this Saturday.
￼
￼
PlayStation: The Concert

Experience your favourite PlayStation worlds like never before at PlayStation: The Concert on 21 April with tickets from just £31.30 each! 

Soundtracks including God of War, The Last of Us, Ghost of Tsushima, and Horizon will be brought to life by state-of-the-art visuals and live musicians. The concert also showcases fan-favourite themes from Bloodborne, Astrobot, Journey, Uncharted, and Helldivers 2. 
Get Tickets
Great events coming soon
￼
￼
THE DOOBIE BROTHERS
Rock & Roll Hall of Famers, The Doobie Brothers head to Birmingham this July featuring the reunited line up of Patrick Simmons, Tom Johnston, John Mc Fee and Michael McDonald. Hear classic hits and new tracks from their first album in 40 years, this is a must-see summer show!
Get Tickets
￼
TORVILL & DEAN: OUR LAST DANCE
Don't miss Torvill & Dean's farewell tour this month! Witness their legendary ice dancing one last time and experience the magic and nostalgia before they retire forever. Tickets are selling fast, best availability on the evening performance on Sunday 27 April.
Get Tickets
￼
LIONEL RICHIE
Lionel Richie's 'Say Hello To The Hits' tour arrives in Birmingham on 9 June! Experience his iconic vocals and timeless classics with a brand-new production. Celebrate one of music's greatest songwriters and entertainers with a nostalgic and energetic performance you won't want to miss! 
Get Tickets
￼
HORSE OF THE YEAR SHOW
Don’t miss the equestrian event of the year with a timetable jam-packed full of action, entertainment and the best horses on the circuit. Shop ‘til you drop at the Retail Village and watch incredible displays of horsemanship in the two arenas. There’s something for everyone – you won’t be disappointed!
Get Tickets
￼
￼
JLS ADD EXTRA DATE IN BRUM

This autumn JLS will return to Utilita Arena Birmingham with their ‘The Club Is Alive: 2025 Hits Tour’. Bringing the full CLUB vibes to Birmingham across TWO nights on Friday 21 and Saturday 22 November 2025, with support from very special guest Example.

Get Tickets
￼
PSSST... CALLING EV DRIVERS
Thanks to bp pulse, EV drivers and their guests get an exclusive pass to the EVIP Lounge at bp pulse LIVE. So if you're heading to an event soon, reserve your spot and enjoy a pre-show bite to eat and drink in the bp pulse EVIP Lounge. 
Book Now
Trending
￼
PAUL CHOWDHRY
MADNESS
THE WOMBATS
BASTILLE
JOHN BISHOP
￼
￼
All information correct at the time of publication. Whilst every effort is made to ensure that all information included in this email is accurate, users are advised that they should take appropriate precautions to verify such information.

subject: Toshi Straps spring sale on now
body:
￼ 
￼ 
It's that time of year again! Shorter nights, warmer weather, and the first green shoots in the garden always raise my spirits. To celebrate I'm launching the annual spring sale at Toshi Straps!

As before, the Toshi Straps spring sale is exclusive to to past customers. It won't be advertised on my website, nor will it be promoted via social media, but if you've received this email it applies to you. Welcome to the Toshi Straps Spring Sale for 2025!

The offer is simple and straightforward. For the next five days, place an order for at least 2 straps on my website, apply the relevant discount code (below) at the checkout, and enjoy the savings:

• For 2 straps, use "2straps15" to get 15% off.
• For 3 straps, use "3straps25" to get 25% off.
• For 4 or more straps, use "4+straps40" to get a massive 40% off. 

So, if you've been thinking of giving your watch a fresh look for the summer, now's the perfect time! Check out my web store to see the great range of leathers I have available.

Need help choosing? I've just published a blog post suggesting a few great leathers for Spring, but if you need more help just email me your watch details and color preferences (to rich@toshi-straps.co.uk) and I'll get back to you with some suggestions.

To redeem your discount, enter the code corresponding to your order at the checkout. Please refer to the T&Cs below for more details.
￼ 
* Terms & Conditions
This offer applies to any order placed via my website where one of the coupon codes above is used at the checkout. Please note - the number of straps in your order determines which of the 3 codes is applicable - any order placed using the wrong code will not be accepted.

This offer is on now, but closes at midnight (BST) on Monday April 7th 2025. Only the cost of straps will be discounted - all gift certificates, additional buckles & accessories are excluded from this offer. This offer cannot be used in conjunction with any any other offer, discount or promotion.

As always, I will give you a scheduled posting date when I email you to confirm your order.
These promotions are always popular, but rest assured I will get your straps built and shipped as quickly as is possible, and I'm confident that when they arrive you will feel they were worth waiting for! 
￼
￼
￼






This email was sent to roger@pembery.com

subject: OpenAI raises $40B 💰, Gemini Robotics Models 🤖, OpenAI Academy 📚
body:
Sign Up |Advertise|View Online 
TLDR 

Together With ￼
TLDR AI 2025-04-02
Why Fortune 100 Insiders Are Backing this AI Marketing Startup (Sponsor) 

You know that moment when a company goes from “never heard of” to “suddenly everywhere? That's RAD Intel's right now. They're helping global brands like Hasbro and Omnicom truly understand the audiences they want to attract in real time — not just guess. It's AI that actually works. Pre-IPO, and legit.

With raving fans at some of the world's largest companies, RAD Intel is on an absolutely crazy trajectory:
📈 Valuation surged from $5M ➡️ $85M.
💰 $37M+ raised across 6,000+ backers, including Google, Amazon + Meta insiders.
🗓️ Q1 2025 contracts have already doubled the total for all of 2024.
Become part of this success. Invest at $0.55/share -- but don't wait, price is changing on April 10th @ 11:59p. 
🚀
Headlines & Launches
OpenAI Announces $40B in New Funding (1 minute read) 

OpenAI has raised $40B at a $300B valuation to support AI research, infrastructure scaling, and its growing user base and partnered with SoftBank to expand AGI development. 
Gemini Robotics from Google DeepMind (6 minute read) 

Google DeepMind has revealed its Gemini Robotics models, which extend Gemini 2.0 with fine-tuning for physical actions. 
OpenAI launches OpenAI Academy, a free AI learning platform for everyone (5 minute read) 

OpenAI has launched OpenAI Academy, a free platform that offers a range of AI courses, from beginner lessons to advanced topics like AI safety and governance. Catering to various audiences, the platform aims to broaden access to AI education and encourage critical thinking about AI's societal impacts. Initial reactions highlight the platform's accessibility and comprehensive approach to demystifying AI for a global audience. 
🧠
Research & Innovation
Video Motion Segmentation (6 minute read) 

Following the recent trend in tracking systems, this work adds dense pixel tracking to improve long term segmentation with Dino and SAM2. 
Open Hands Coding Model (8 minute read) 

A strong 32B model trained with RL on top of Qwen that surpasses many substantially larger models on agentic coding tasks. 
Open-Reasoner-Zero: An Open Source Approach to Scaling Up Reinforcement Learning on the Base Model (30 minute read) 

There is a huge open question in RL reasoning efforts whether or not a strong enough base model is required and necessary for emergent reasoning. This work explored many cases of scaling RL on a base mode. It found that strong base models are very helpful for reasoning convergence. 
🧑‍💻
Engineering & Resources
Easi3R: Estimating Disentangled Motion from DUSt3R Without Training (GitHub Repo) 

Easi3R is a 3D vision system that can better estimate 3D scenes with high motion. It improves substantially over previous methods in full scene reconstruction. This was achieved by masking moving objects and learning those and the background separately. 
Benchmark for RL-based Video Understanding (GitHub Repo) 

SEED-Bench-R1 is a benchmark that evaluates post-training methods like RL and SFT for multimodal LLMs in complex video-based tasks, showing RL's strengths in perception and data efficiency but challenges in logical coherence. 
Flow Prediction for Autonomous Driving (GitHub Repo) 

UniOcc is a unified framework for forecasting and flow prediction in driving scenarios built for multi-dataset training and cross-domain evaluation in both real and synthetic environments. 
🎁
Miscellaneous
Nexthop AI Locks up $110M Led by Lightspeed (2 minute read) 

Nexthop AI secured $110 million led by Lightspeed Venture Partners to enhance networking solutions for hyperscalers, focusing on cost and power efficiency. The round also saw participation from Kleiner Perkins, WestBridge Capital, Battery Ventures, and Emergent Ventures. CEO Anshul Sadana emphasized Nexthop AI's role in innovating alongside cloud companies. 
Alibaba Head Warns AI Industry Is Showing Signs of Bubble (3 minute read) 

Alibaba chairman Joe Tsai warns of a potential AI bubble due to massive investments in data centers without clear demand. Despite $52 billion committed to AI development, concerns are rising about overinvestment. Recent disruptions like Chinese startup DeepSeek highlight investor fears of overpaying in the AI sector. 
Insights from Claude 3.7 Sonnet (4 minute read) 

Anthropic has introduced the Economic Index, which uses Claude Sonnet 3.7 to assess AI's influence on different job sectors. The model evaluates how AI affects productivity, automation risks, and labor market trends. This initiative aims to provide data-driven insights for policymakers and businesses navigating AI-driven economic shifts. 
⚡
Quick Links
Amazon's Alexa Fund is now backing AI startups (3 minute read) 

Amazon's Alexa Fund is expanding its investment focus to include AI startups, investing in companies like NinjaTech AI, Hedra, Ario, and HeyBoss. 
AI-powered therapy shows shocking results in mental health study (4 minute read) 

A Dartmouth study found that AI therapy chatbot Therabot significantly reduced symptoms in participants with depression, anxiety, and eating disorders. 
Databricks Has a Trick That Lets AI Models Improve Themselves (5 minute read) 

Databricks has developed Test-time Adaptive Optimization (TAO), a method that leverages reinforcement learning and synthetic data to improve AI models without the need for clean labeled data.
